Tinkered these parts for the lounge room curtains. Made these items for some 30mm by 10mm pulleys with an 8mm bearing hole. Originally was going to use M8 bolts I had but when I screwed the bolts into the two pulley holders it just didn't look right so Tinkered the pins to match. The handles were made as an after thought as I was going to use continuous cord.
Designed in Tinkercad.

Notice:
The Flutter Scout RC Car is created by Alexander Taylor and all the credit goes to him.
https://github.com/tlalexander/Flutter-Scout
https://makezine.com/projects/3d-print-badass-rc-race-car/

So I liked the concept, but if we are 3D printing a R/C car why buy expensive bearings and tires when we can 3D print bushings and wheels and tires.

Note: Print the tire, then flip it 180° in x or y to get 2 that match when you put them on the car.

Front wheels and associated parts are in process of being designed and printed...

title: 3D Systems Cube 3 cartridge mod V2 (NOW ADJUSTABLE!)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Two good news for all you Cube 3 owners
No.1:
You can now adjust the filament grip with this modified extruder-box. Not every filament has exactly the thickness of the original filament. With a simple adjustment of the screws you can prevent clogging.

No.2:
Brace yourself......The Cube 3 Firmware has been HACKED!!! :D Some brilliant guys (not me :P) successfully made a Toolbox, to modify the original Firmware, so that it doesn't overwrite the DRM-chip. I was sceptical first but I can confirm that IT WORKS!!! FINALLY the Cube is unchained!!!! :D
Here's the download link with all the instructions you need:
http://www.openbuilds.com/threads/cube-3-pro-hacks.8420/
many many thanks to these guys for their efforts!

Additional Material used:
-Festo QSM-3 (3mm to 3mm)
(I've got mine from here: http://www.der-schweighofer.ch/artikel/69867 )
-PTFE OD 3mm/ID 2mm
-screws M3x16mm (6Pcs)
-2x springs from the inside the extruder nozzle of two empty original cartridges

Aswell you will need:
-electric drill
-M3 thread cutter
-screw driver-set
I
I
PLEASE print piece2 separately and with SUPPORTS ON
I
I
The Cube 3 cartridges are well known for beeing unreliable. At least mine tend to break themselve every second time I'm trying to print something. My biggest problem was the tube releasing itself from the little CNC piece mounted to every cartridge. I think the pressure is just to high trough all those sharp angles. So I modified the tubing aswell. Just cut the upper part of the original plastic piece from the extruder needle. Tube used is 1xID2mm/OD3mm (380mm).
You can change the filament by disconnecting the tube from the Festo connector, cut the filament flush to the tube, insert the new filament just trough the cogwheel and leave it just before the festo connector begins. Put all together again and make a test-print until the new filament is trough.

description.text:
Needed a little storage tube for the glue I use on the hotbed.
Also was getting use to using Tinkercad.

Good exercise in 3D CAD work as I had never before tried anything like this.

Everyone needs an army of little yellow minions to do stuff for them. Now you can generate an infinite number of minions to do your bidding! Note that there are only 30,000 unique names generated, so if you print more than 30,000 of them, you may need to apply nicknames or titles. :-) UPDATED
  • Added random Minion generation
  • Now with rockets and bombs!
  • Made faces, leg positions, etc., much more expressive.

Instructions
=
Create a minion to do your bidding. Print him. Repeat until you need a larger evil lair.
  • Number (this generates the Minion) . Putting in 0 generates a random Minion, meaning you have no idea what will come out!. The number of the minion is displayed under them in the preview, and is printed on the base for easy reference.
    • You can print out the minion in one piece, with supports, or in three pieces to assemble (glue together). If you have a large format printer, you can print all three pieces assembled on one plate. Suggestions Wanted

  • If you have suggestions, please post them here. For example, what poses, hair styles, clothing or props would you like to see?

    • Bug
    • There appears to be a bug in the version of OpenSCAD running in Customizer currently, causing Minion's hair to go crazy sometimes. If you see that, just try another minion number. Or download the script and run it in OpenSCAD yourself.

print_settings.Notes:: Wind Turbine Assy - the 2xM3 Self tapping screws should be M4 Self tapping screws.

description.text:
https://youtu.be/_NhGP7Bfk18
MKII 5 Watt 3d printable Wind Turbine with passive variable pitch mechanism. All Printable parts can be printed without the use of supports minimising post processing.

Attribution
https://youtu.be/rkLW1EaWEb0 Before the Flood - the aim is to reduce my carbon footprint 1 Renewable Watt at a time whilst giving others the same opportunity without the burden of the design, testing, manufacture and optimisation of this complex Turbine.

Description
The MkII has three design improvements, the first is an all important tail fin to allow the turbine to turn into the wind and extract the maximum wind energy in changeable conditions, the second is a stiffer tower structure with bigger bearings and increased diameter locating pin to support the increased loads from the tail whilst allowing for the third improvement which is the inclusion of Split Ring Electronics. The Split Ring Electronics allows the turbine to spin around the tower axis without any limitations it brings the power electronics into the tower where there is more space and its easier to access.

This fully functional wind turbine has been specifically design to be manufactured, assembled and operated at home with its unique 3d printable design. The wind turbine is optimized to produce a power output of 5 Watt (12volt ~0.4amps) at 5m/s wind speeds, perfect for battery charging applications.

The wind turbine has been designed with a unique Passive Variable Pitch (PVP) design. The PVP maintains an optimum power output through control of the turbines rotational speed. Whilst optimizing power output the PVP also protects the Turbine from dangerous over speed conditions, limiting its maximum revolutions per minute in wind speeds greater than 5m/s.

The main components of the turbine have been designed for Additive Layer Manufacturing (ALM) methods using PLA plastic. 95% of the ALM components require no post processing as these parts do not require ‘print supports’ reducing material usage whilst improving the overall finish of the part.

UPGRADES
If you search "mkII 5 watt 3d printable wind turbine" on google you will find some upgraded parts for the wind turbine things like:

-Blade split into two parts for easy printing
-2GT Belt drive option for reduced noise and higher gear ratios
-A protective cover for the Shaft Nut to ensure no rotating items contact the electrics
-An alternate Tower header diameter and slip ring assembly design for a smaller diameter tower pole

You will also find some pictures/videos and general discussion and advice on printing, assembly and operation.

Thanks Dan

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

Contact me if you require a printing service.

Materials, Speeds and Feeds, Temperatures, Infill and layer settings are listed in the Instruction Manual. The assembly has been specifically design for these settings, printing outside of these setting may affect the fit, form and function of the turbine.

Rotor Assy - there should be 6xM3 machine screws called out as item 14 in the lower right view and then 3xM4 self tapping screws in the upper view attaching the nose cone to the disc. Sorry I made a last minute change and didn't catch this...

Wind Turbine Assy - the 2xM3 Self tapping screws should be M4 Self tapping screws.

comments.text: Hi jperaud, There is no issue with the routing of wires from the slip ring into the tower. The hole in the pin is elliptical the wires pass either side of the M6 threaded rod. Install the slip ring into the pin and run the wire through the hole. Install the pin into the structure. Put a screw driver down the hole used to insert the M6 rod and push the wires to either side, carefully insert the M6 rod using the screw driver to move the wires.

comments.text:
The first thing that springs to mind is the method of inserting screws. I would forget self tappers and use machine screws. The hole for the screw will be the std tapping size and as deep as possible. I usually start the thread with a tap or a modded screw about 2 turns deep and then use the screw. It will force the plastic around the screw making for a very strong and servicable thread. Most threads that are "cut" into the plasic will not survive tinkering.
I hope this helps.

print_settings.Notes:: You will probably need supports for the cutouts of the ball bearings.

title: Modified Prusa i3 MK2 Spoolholder with ball bearing

description.text:
I modified the original spoolholder of the Prusa i3 MK2 and added ball bearings.
The ball bearings ensure that the spool unwinds more easily.
It also prevents the spool from wobbling while unwinding thanks to the two ball bearings on each spoolholder.

I also included a printable ball bearing (nothing special) in case you don't have one.
It should do the job :)

You need to print the following parts:
1x Spoolholder_right
1x Spoolholder_left
4x Axis
4x Ball_Bearing (optional)

Printer:

Prusa i3 MK2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Notes:

You will probably need supports for the cutouts of the ball bearings.

1. Remove all supports.
  2. Place a ball bearing in the cutout.
  3. Put a axis push it through the hole.
  4. Repeat 1-3 for the other ball bearings.

To remove the ball bearings, push someting through the hole on the back.
The axis will fall out.

The original thing this is based on was angled the opposite way that I needed for my fridge, which resulted in too much space between the clips, so the bar that these insert into would fall out.

I also reinforced the area that the bar attaches to with some wedges.

I printed this in ABS, with supports, at 50% infill, 0.2mm layer height. I printed it exactly as it is positioned in the STL file so the layers would provide the most strength to the part that clips into the door itself. Yes, this results in a lot of support material. UPDATE: Printing it flat on the bed works just fine. Adjust the angle by 7 degrees, and it will print flat.

Update: Fixed a problem where one of the support wedges wasn't intersecting correctly.

title: Monoprice Mini 40mm Full Coverage Fan Shroud

description.text:
A 40mm fan shroud I've been working on as an upgrade for my mini. I only am printing in PLA so have been trying to improve cooing around the parts. I currently am using the R01 as the R00 doesn't fit very well. R01 fits great but I haven't had much time to test its improvement over the stock.

R01 doesn't work well, too much restriction for good cooling airflow. I used some tape to modify the area cooling the hotend and saw some improvement but still worse than stock. I'll rework the design and post files once completed.

R02 is much better for a better flow restriction on the heatsink. Unfortunately a step backwards in ease of printing. I am currently using a cheap replacement nozzle which is ~2mm longer than stock.

UPDATE: R03 is a improved version for those of you who would like to have a full time hot end fan (30mm) and a separate print cooling fan (40mm). It will print standing on the 40mm fan mount with minimal supports.

I included the source solidworks files for you to use if you'd like to modify for your own use.

Printer:

Monoprice Mini Select

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

50%

Notes:

I designed this to be solid at 3-4 perimeters with a 0.4 mm nozzle. Requires support.
This is the first project I've used Solidworks Flow Simulation to try to optimize the air flow and balance the restrictions on the heat brake cooling as well as the nozzle.

description.text: The purpose of this compression mounted stop is to restrict the Z travel at its minimum and maximum. Just make sure they are mounted nice and tight about 1mm below your min/max Z travel. I remixed this thingi from an awesome coupler designed by Loco http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:602481. Enjoy

This part was made with Tinkercad. Edit the part online at: https://tinkercad.com/things/gEbUCbv8TDz - This is a mockup of the pieces put together. See below for individual files. The beauty of this set is that it has self contained storage and you can even save your game! Each board piece has a little hole in the middle, as do the chess pieces themselves. If you have to pack up your game before you are done playing, you can just start stacking the board pieces with the chess piece still inside and then use a string or similar to link all of the pieces together. Then, when you have made it to camp, or landed, just un-string all of the pieces in the reverse order and put your board back together. This set is strictly a utilitarian chess set so fanciness was kept to a minimum for quick and simple printing. You will notice there are a bunch of different files for the different side and corner pieces. Make sure you count properly when printing - or print some extras incase you lose some (the beauty of making your own pieces)

chess_pieces_layout.stl (https://tinkercad.com/things/3VkAwaFB2JT) - print 1 set in one color and 1 set in another color travel_chess_set_square.stl (https://tinkercad.com/things/kwbmmScqa74) - print 18 in one color and 18 in another color for the interior squares --this is where it gets tricky and maybe one day I will make it easier and more clear. travel_chess_set_edge.stl (https://tinkercad.com/things/7bgffrJSptZ) - Print 12 of single cutout pieces (6 in each color) and 6 of each 2 cutout pieces (3 of each color) travel_chess_set_corner.stl (https://tinkercad.com/things/i9X1dSlazFT) - Wait until the end to print these to make sure you get the right colors. print 1 of the 2 cutout piece, 2 of the 1 cutout pieces, and 1 of the 0 cutout pieces (2 tabs). Maybe there's a better cutout/tab layout, but this seemed easiest to me at the time. Please feel free to derive and fix.

title: Battat Driver Set with Part Organizer

description.text:
My boys received two take-apart Battat toys this Christmas. Probably one of the best toys they have. The kits come with battery powered drills, but I designed these accessories to give them some basic hand tool and organization practice. Don't over tighten, apply proper pressure to a Phillips-head driver so you don't strip the screw, don't scatter small parts everywhere, etc. They work great!

On my to-do list is to reverse-engineer the screws, nuts, and other small parts for custom projects.

Timelapse of the print:
https://youtu.be/XvIGYAJ2jyc

Printer:

Fusion3 F400-S

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.25mm

Infill:

25%

Notes:

These are designed to print without supports in the orientation seen in the part preview images. If your bridging performance isn't that great, you may need support. Three of the pictures I added show how mine came out without support.

The 25% infill was to make sure the parts hold up to rough use.

I didn't use a raft or a brim, but you may need one if you have trouble with adhesion.

I printed without supports, so post processing is easy. Depending on your print settings, you may have to sand/trim the bottom of the drivers and handle so they will fit properly. I uploaded images to show these points.

Assembly is just a matter of pushing the drivers into the handles. I didn't use glue since they fit snug. You may have to apply a good bit of pressure, but they should slide all the way in if your printer is calibrated properly. If you are having trouble getting them to fit, I would scale the driver portion down just a little bit. Maybe 5% or less.

Reverse Engineering Process

I could have designed something that was close, but I wanted everything to work just like the OEM bits. I scanned the bits with an Artec Space Spider 3D scanner and reverse-engineered the parts in SolidWorks.

I designed the organizer and driver handle from scratch.

title: Simple Spool Holder for Spools with 53.5mm Hole

description.text:
Filament spool holder for spools with a 53.5mm hole. To use with 608 bearings on an M8 threaded rod. I used some old ABEC-5 skateboard bearings, they work pretty well.

The hole for the bearing is on the inside just to make a better look, I'm thinking of making a version with them on the outside as well, because you could fix the hole thing better with a washer and nut. But it's good enough for me for now.

They come in two versions, version 1 has a tighter fit, you might have to work a bit to make the bearings fit. Version 2 has a bit of a looser fit, but still working just fine. Outer dimension is the same, because for my case, it fits perfectly. Just try for yourself!

title: MachTach gear tooth sensor mount for 9" South Bend lathe

description.text:
This allows the MachTach gear tooth sensor to be mounted behind the head stock so that the sensor can run against the 76 tooth bull gear. You might need to upgrade an older unit by buying a new microprocessor chip from Henry.
The slot in the back of the base is for a 1/4-20 nut. the hole in the bottom of the base will take a 1-1/2" 1/4-20 bolt which is used to clamp the base to the V-way using the shoe. Clean out the hole with a 1/4" drill bit. Run a 1/4-20 tap through the hole in the top of the base mount. The top piece can be moved so that the attached sensor is positioned close the gear teeth. Then use a short screw to clamp the top piece and hold it in position.
I included a photo of the unit sitting on the v-way in front of the chuck in order to show how it is put together. It is difficult to get a good picture when it is installed in its working position behind the head stock. But you can see it in the working position in the second picture.
I used small wood screws to fasten the sensor mount to the top piece, and thick crazy glue to attach the cover plate. I wanted a cover plate to protect the sensor pcb from oil and stray swarf. You might have to trim the cover plate to get a good fit.
I have included the Sketchup files for those of you who want to change (or fix) things.

title: EiiiCooler for Wanhao Duplicator i3 / Maker Select
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
The EiiiCooler is a cooler for your cold end and extruder motor of the Duplicator i3.

[RECOMMENDED RADIAL FANS]
Duplicator i3 V1, V2, V2.1 (12V): www.banggood.com/3D-Printer-12V-DC-50mm-Blow-Radial-Cooling-Fan-p-980653.html
Duplicator i3 PLUS (24V): www.banggood.com/3Pcs-DC24V-Cooling-Fan-Ultra-Quiet-Turbine-Small-DC-Blower-5015-For-3D-Printer-Circuit-Board-p-1110725.html
(For the 24V fan you may have to switch cable orientation in the connector to fit the PLUS)

You'll get much higher airflow by using a radial fan through the heatsink as well as into the extruder gear area compared to what the axial fan can provide.

Top reasons why to use the EiiiCooler:
1) You're certain to get a very high flow-rate of cold air across the hotend heatsink!
2) You'll get more airflow into the extruder gear area!
3) No more fiddling with those annoying white plastic spacers anymore during maintenance, they're not needed anymore.
4) Much more difficult to accidentally damage the radial fan with screwdriver compared to an axial fan. (Probably the #1 cause of axial fan death on the Duplicator i3!)

Top reasons why not to use the EiiiCooler:
1) You want things super quiet.
2) You dont care about your printer feeling well :(

Please note that this is not a 3D performance output booster in any means, but it does solve some potential issues the default setup has. E3D team has reported that almost half of problems reported on their hotends is due to insufficient cooling of the coldend.

[REQUIRED HARDWARE]
1 pcs M4x20 screw (or longer)
1 pcs M4 nut (or locknut)
1 pcs 51x51x15 mm radial fan (Look at Delta BFB0512HH for dimensions datasheet)

(According to the makers of the E3D hotend, almost half the issues their costumer has, has been linked to insufficient cold end cooling. Read more about it here if you're interested, they can explain it better than I can: https://wiki.e3d-online.com/wiki/E3D-v6_Troubleshooting )

comments.text: Wonderful! Thank you so much for this yet again outstanding contribution to the community! :)

comments.text: Happy to hear, hope someone will find a use for it too :)

comments.text: So is that 50mm fan cooling the coolend and the hotend?
comments.author: morriscode

comments.text:
The radial fan is only cooling the cold end and extruder, blowing the air out the back.
Nothing should be cooling the hot end (should stay hot)
comments.author: morriscode

comments.text: I meant like is it cooling the extruder and the nozzle? I see you have another Cii/Dii cooler down below, i'm assuming that has it's own fan? Or just a picture from the back would answer my question.
comments.author: Pawpawpaw85

comments.text:
It's correct the Ciii/DiiiCooler uses their own fan since it needs to be controlled by software to apply cooling when/where needed on the printed part.
This fan for the cold end is wired to run 100% of the time the machine is turned on and is not software control, it only cools the cold end and extruder.

title: Alignment tube for Focusing Umbrella - Selens 16 rod 90~190cm

description.text:
This tube allows you to keep a light centered in a photographic umbrella. This goes into the end of a piece of speedrail tubing, I.D. 25.50mm, and allows a center shaft,O.D. 17.20mm, to stay centered in the umbrella. There is also a tab cut out to lock the center shaft in place when positioning the light.
I originally used a piece of pvc tubing but it was the center shaft was very loose. I only recently learned how to use Sketchup to produce this.
The light is revered so the light is never direct, but it can be focused from spot to flood.
It has worked very good so far.
It took about 3hrs printing fast with a Ultimaker 2+ (PLA).
The Umbrella was purchased from Amazon. Selens 16 rod 120cm umbrella:
https://www.amazon.com/Selens-36-Reflector-Mount-Speedlight/dp/B013UXHGW8?th=1

remixed_from.author: sj_baird
remixed_from.title: Tevo Tarantula Dual Extruder with sensor and 50mm radial fan ports. V3.0

title: Tevo Tarantula Dual Extruder with sensor and 50mm radial fan ports.
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I designed this to be a template for cutting a 1/8th inch (3mm) aluminum sheet. It could be printed as well.

In this version i have utilized a lower duct under the gantry so you'll need to lower the extruder. This is why the sensor mount can be printed separately. I have uploaded additional files to eliminate this but you wont be able to get the lower duct under the gantry.

I have decided that the cooling was great but I wanted access to the set screw for the heat breaks. SO i turned the extruder around, and also designed a blower duct because I was not happy with the tiny 30mm fan's cooling. (As I suspected)

The lower duct only needs bed supports because I designed it to be printed without. I believe I used .2mm layer height. (The connection points need beefed up Ill work on it, but you can print as is and superglue it together.)

Print the Front duct with the extruder face down using bed supports as well, I have included a version with built in supports if needed for the mounting slot, otherwise this was also designed to not need additional supports.

I have also redesigned the duct supports to include an air filter. I just use an air conditioning filter and cut it to size, but you might be able to use something like a coffee filter, The benefit here is it should aid in filtering your print fumes and protect your fans from getting dirty. If you don't want the filter then you'll need to shim the lower part as its spaced for accommodation of the filter.

I have printed this thing but have not assembled. The fit seems perfectly tight :)

(Update 5/16/2017)
OK thinkers, I have finally added more material to for the rear ducts attachment screw, although it clicked in fin for me and I have been using it without a screw since I uploaded the original.
I have also removed two of the supports on the lower duct to give more air flow. Although again the original has had great cooling for bridging. I have not tested either yet.

I am going to be converting to direct drive extruders and am going to expand this design to accommodate them..

All in all I was very satisfied with this design and its functionality, however, I have some 3mm filament that Bowden extruders have trouble pushing through the PTFE tubing. I also want to use at least one filament width sensor and they work best on direct drive extruders.

(Update 5/16/2017)
Uploaded the direct drive files not tested, will print test and remix soon.

description.text:
I got fed up cutting wood for my scratch built mini arrows so I made this to slide into the plane instead. I like to mess around with motors so being friction fit I can just slide in a different set up if I'm in the mood. This mount is designed to work with the metal spacer you get with a lot of cheap motors, figured that was sensible because some of my 4s setups run hot after heavy use the holes are spaced 30mm apart and the holes themselves are 3mm. An m3 metric screw goes in nicely and won't come out if you go easy on the torque (no need for a nut on the back if you gently tighten it).

This should work on other flite test planes that use the smaller motor mount but I haven't tested that yet? I uploaded the Sketchup file too so you can modify the original to suit your needs...enjoy, I love the mini arrow, its fast, cheap to make, isn't fussy what you stick on it and is so easy to make they're nearly disposable :)

title: bras de fixation pour le comparateur

description.text:
Il faut percer le haut et le bas en diametre 6  
En haut, le haut se fixe sur le support du ventilo  
En bas, percer pour fixer le comparateur  
Une fois le comparateur fixé, descendez Z jusqu'a ce que le comparateur touche le lit chauffant  
ensuite, déplacer le lit et regler la hauteur identique partout  
Refaite plusieurs fois car le serrage d'un coté du plateau dérègle les autres cotés  
ensuite, démonter le comparateur et vérifier l'espace de 0.25mm entre le nez et le lit grâce à  un jeu de cales

title: Upper glove compartment organizer for 3rd gen Prius

description.text:
Helps to keep objects from sliding around in the upper portion of the glove compartment. Fits a 3rd generation Prius, but should also fit the 2nd gen as well (I think the dimensions are nearly the same?) Use rubber bumpers for additional stability.

As you can see in the picture it does not fit from end to end. I made it this way because my printer's maximum length is just under 9". Of course you could always scale it to a perfect fit with your slicer. I would leave the depth (plus height) as is however, as it allows the door to close just fine.

Also included two versions, 1st one with a complete base and the 2nd with a partial base. Reason is because this should be printed in ABS in order to withstand temperature extremes, and with my printer, the more ABS touches the bed surface the more it warps.

Dimensions are: 8 1/2" length, 4" depth, 2" height.

description.text:
This is a handrest for the SpaceNavigator Desktop edition. Your SpaceNavigator won't move around anymore when using it!

There are 2 parts to print, and a few things to stick on after printing (optional).
*Edit April 30th 2017: You can now print the pad with soft material if you want to (I added the pad as a STL file).

-The main part is the "SpaceNavigator Handrest.stl". This is the handrest, and there is a shallow pocket where the foam pad goes (see the 3d model pictures, 1 has the triangular
shaped pocket, it is this one). This is the one I recommend printing.

-Then there is the "SpaceNavigator Cap.stl". This goes under the handrest and snaps in place, preventing the SpaceNavigator from coming out. It is removable.

-If you don't want the triangular pocket on the handrest, then use the file "SpaceNavigator Handrest-No Pocket.stl".

-There is a PDF file, called "SpaceNavigator Pad Shape.pdf". Print this, and put it over top of the foam pad to cut the shape, then it will fit right in that triangle pocket.

Printer:

Prusa i3 acrylic frame

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

No supports needed.

For the foam sheet, I used this:
http://canada.michaels.com/on/demandware.store/Sites-MichaelsCanada-Site/en_CA/Product-Show?pid=10337027&cgid=
It's something like 2$ per sheet if I remember right... It is roughly 0.100" thick. You'll find this easily in any arts and craft store (adhesive foam sheet).

To limit the slippery effect, I used some Pro-Tec self sticking 3/4" round bumper pads, like this below (you'll find this, or similar, is any hardware store):
https://www.madicoinc.com/ca/en/category/floor-surface-protection/pro-tec-surface-protection/pro-tec-pvc-round-bumper-pads/1059526/sku-23123

If you print it, please upload a picture of it, it would be greatly appreciated!

title: Doll Table
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a small table for dolls to sit at. Will design matching chairs in a bit.

Photos will be uploaded when it is done printing. It is rather large at nearly 120mm by 120mm!

Printer:

Tevo Tarantula

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Printed at 0.3mm in BambooFill. I'm planning on adjusting the temperature between the legs and the tabletop so that there is contrast, as I've heard you can do that with bamboofill. Haven't tried it yet, so here's hoping it goes well.

I used concentric lines infill, as I prefer it instead of diagonals. Diagonals engage two motors at once which, on a rather relatively unstable printing platform like the Tevo Tarantula, would lead me to believe there's an increased risk of slight displacement. One motor, one direction, a bit easier.

The concentric lines also have less overlap with the perimeter shells, which I prefer.

Designed in TinkerCAD.

https://www.tinkercad.com/things/32ymuj3IvpI-doll-table

print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

description.text:
A plinko style dice tower designed for d&d. It's open faced so you can see the action, but the dice won't fall out of the angled pegs.

See how it works here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sI64v1gKJUo

During play it assembles to provide:

  • the dice tower
  • a tray for dice to roll into
  • a platform for frequently used dice and minis
  • a pencil holder
  • a small storage pocket
  • additional space for other dice.

After play, it packs up into a portable little box that can store pencils, dice, and minis.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

30%

Notes:

3/11/17 update: I reprinted organizer.stl with support (just touching the build plate, not everywhere). The depressions on the top came out a lot nicer. In Cura 2.4 I used support type "lines" and set the Z distance to 0.15.

All STLs are oriented the way they should be printed. No supports are needed if printed this way. For the dice tower, I used a 1.2mm shell and 30% infill to make sure the pegs were tough.

The shell for the organizer and case was 0.8mm. These parts can also be printed with a lower infill. The organizer piece does involve a good amount of bridging, but it should still turn out ok. The indentations for holding dice up top came out a little rough for me, but they work fine.

Notes:

  • The pegs on my first prototype were brittle. Besides beefing up the design a bit, printing a temperature tower to find what temperature gave me the best layer strength helped a lot. I used http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:915435 and then broke it to test strength.
  • If your steps/mm are not properly set for all three axes, the pieces may not fit together well. See http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1278865 for more info

comments.text: The tower its self using slanted pegs to keep the dice in is brilliant. Nice design

title: letterless YAGI WLAN Antenna EXTENSION for 2.4 GHz

description.text: This is a modification to Photonix's antenna that skeins better than the original. I imported his STL into Sketchup and replaced the faces with the letters with flat surfaces. SFACT was filling in solid layers where the letters protruded (about half of the object).

Please see Photonix's thing http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:19548 for directions and rod lengths. 'A' is on the rear side of the hole for the transmitting element. 'B' through 'F' continue in order to the end. SFACT chucked an error at me during one of the layers, but it printed well nonetheless. I have yet to try it, but I will update when I have results. This printed well on my Makergear Prusa with the fill down to 0.15 (natural PLA).

description.text:
Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2060894

Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=2060894

Any clue why:
// Which one would you like to see?// Which one would you like to see?
part = true; // [true:wholeRing,false:one strand]

Isn't being recognized as it is said to be in the customizer documentation:
http://customizer.makerbot.com/docs#multi

Using the following options:

ringheight = 3
$fn = 9
periods = 6
sizeValue = 11
thickness = 2
Country = United States
step = 5

comments.text:
Sure, part is a special variable in Customizer.
It doesn't seem to handle booleans like true/false gracefully .
(probably because expressions that need evaluation are not allowed as default values in Customizer ).
try using something like 0 and 1 or "Bob" and "Uncle" instead.
http://customizer.makerbot.com/docs#multi

title: TEVO BLACK WIDOW FLEXION E3D EXTRUDER MOUNT

description.text:
Mounts Flexion Extruder to the Tevo Black Widow with a E3D V6 hotend.
Factory V6 clone hotend can be used with minor drilling of clone V6 heat sink And/or trimming of the flexion's PTFE tube. Use of genuine E3D hotend is recommended for increased performance

Required Parts
-Flexion E3D Extruder
-NEMA17 Stepper Motor currently using a 48mm Version ( Factory Black Widow Extruder Motor can not be used do to shaft being turned down to accept gear for the 5:1 planetary gear box)
-Hardware will be listed soon
-Flexible Filament to enjoy how amazing the Flexion Extruder works

BLT touch Mount and Adapters for ducts will be available soon

title: Honda and Toyota Brake Pedal Stop Pad - Customizable

description.text:
Based on the OpenSCAD file from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:924433 Thanks MS3FGX for the original!

Added the retention bump so this part can be printed with flexible TPU filament and may stay in better than the straight style stop pad.

Click the "open in customizer" button on the right side of this page to specify your exact dimensions and create your own custom STL file. Or download the open source SCAD file and edit it that way.

Default dimensions to fit a 2004 Toyota Corolla. But these parts seem to be pretty standard between Toyota and Honda from what I'm hearing and is the same basic shape as the Dorman 74015 aftermarket part.

If you try out other dimensions for different vehicles please list them in the comments section for others to use.

By - http://www.easybotics.com/
And - http://hilo90mhz.com/

description.text: This is another version of the adapter to allow you to make use of the makerbot style plastruder tip on a mendel. This fits just below the extruder stepper assembly.

place the two m3 nuts in the captive nut sockets.  Add or remove m3 washers as needed to adjust seating of the thermal insulator.  For mendel extruders which have the slot in place, add a section of insulator to fill the hole for the insulator, or print a new extruder without the insulator hole.

description.text:
If you think that your airsoft G36 AEG doesn't look manly enought, this is the solution for you! Add this manly accessory to your riffle to show all the other players how high your testosterone levels! is!

IMPORTANT!
Be sure to print the base_test_piece first. It will help you see if the holes line up properly and will also show you the 2 holes you got to make in order to fix the Tac Sac. It uses 2 M2.6x16mm screws. Be sure to place the motor crew in the motor plate before screwing the Tac Sac to the motor plate. Then you can assemble the Lower receiver to the gearbox.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

8%

Notes:

Be sure to place the flat face of the part on the bottom on the bed with the rounded parts pointing up. The angle is 55% so printing it in PLA should be fine at 0.2mm with appropriate cooling. Go for 0.1mm for a better finish.

Change Customize the words on the front of the LCD in FreeCAD, Export as STL and print

FreeCAD

Open in FreeCAD, then expand Fillet002-Fillet001-Main-Words- then modify the words in their respective ShapeStringXXX-String

You may need to delete and redo the Fillet's after as sometimes it wont rebuild

after you have done that i recommend that in the Part View, you highlight the part then goto Part->Refine Shape
Then export the created part and print
